user external Id to prevent dups, especially if you know it's unique.

choices.B: Upload the CSV into a custom object related to Candidate__c.
choices.A: Update the SSN__c field definition to mark it as an External Id.
choices.D: Create a Process Builder on the Candidate__c object to map the records.
choices.C: Create a before insert trigger to correctly map the records.

questions.question_text:
A SSN__c custom field exists on the Candidate__c custom object. The field is used to store each candidate's social security number and is marked as Unique in the schema definition.
As part of a data enrichment process, Universal Containers has a CSV file that contains updated data for all candidates in the system. The file contains each
Candidate's social security number as a data point. Universal Containers wants to upload this information into Salesforce, while ensuring all data rows are correctly mapped to a candidate in the system.
Which technique should the developer implement to streamline the data upload?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
We use isAccessible() – before querying

Selected Answer: BC
B) Schema.sObjectType.<objectApiName>.isAccessible(): This method checks if the current user has read access to the specified object.

C) Schema.sObjectType.<objectApiName>.fields.<fieldApiName>.isUpdateable(): This method checks if the specified field on the object is updateable by the current user.

Selected Answer: BD
those are the correct answers

comments.content: And the question asks for the object access, not field level access.

This
Question even nudges you to think about some 10k limit

And try/catch shouldn't be used with DML exceptions
https://www.crmscience.com/single-post/2020/05/20/how-salesforce-developers-handle-errors-with-try-catch-rollback-best-practices

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Total number of records processed as a result of DML statements is 10k so if your list has over 10k records, database.update will fail.

Selected Answer: B
has over 10,000 records == +10,000 records
When you run it in Salesforce you will get:
System.LimitException: Too many DML rows: 10001

Answer is B
System.LimitException: Too many DML rows: 10001

Selected Answer: B
When you hit a Governor Limit Exception, it terminates the entire transaction. Your application will terminate with an unhandleable exception

comments.content: You will see when you test it. Try catch won't catch the exception.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I would go with the C:
System.LimitException: Too many DML rows: 10001 is DmlException that is thrown by the Database.update statement! In a try-catch block the exception is handled (DmlException extends Exception)

Selected Answer: B
In this example, the code updates 50,000 Case records, which exceeds the limit of 10,000 records per DML statement. Therefore, the transaction will fail due to exceeding the governor limit, and an exception will be thrown.
The org has over 10000 records as per the question hence answer is B , tried and tested

Selected Answer: B
Note that the update statement in in the For loop, and will fail after 150 DML statements

comments.content: There's no such statement inside For loop!
And the exception is thrown because case record is more than 10000.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
I have Executed This in my org and it is throwing LimitException

Selected Answer: A
I agree with noox here. To elaborate on his point:
It isn't B because no governor limits are being exceeded.
It isn't C because we are utilizing Database.update with allOrNone set to false, meaning any updates that potentially fail will not result in an overall failure.
It isn't D because Limit Exceptions cannot be caught.
I think the answer is B - the DML error will be thrown due to OVER 10,000 records. right?

Selected Answer: A
SOQL can retrieve 50.000 records. 
The org has only 10.000 records. 
The records are placed inside a list.
Then the entire list is updated. So DML count is 1/150.

comments.content: Hum, it might be B, you can hit the heapSize limit with 10.000+ records in a list...

discussion.content:
No I think A is correct:
Total number of records retrieved by SOQL queries 50,000
Ans. is B

choices.B: The transaction will fail due to exceeding the governor limit.
choices.A: The transaction will succeed and changes will be committed.
choices.D: The try/catch block will handle exceptions thrown by governor limits.
choices.C: The try/catch block will handle any DML exceptions thrown.

discussion.content: Why not A？

comments.content: You are right, answer is A. This is followed link about that. https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.pages.meta/pages/pages_controller_extension.htm

https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.pages.meta/pages/pages_controller_extension.htm

Overrides are defined by whichever methods are defined in the “leftmost” extension, or, the extension that is first in the comma-separated list. Thus, the save method of extensionA is overriding the method of extensionB.
But it says they have save methods. So the method in standardcontroller is never invoked.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
You can override save method with extension, and "leftmost" extension gets the priority over the rest.

Selected Answer: A
Overrides are defined by whichever methods are defined in the “leftmost” extension, or, the extension that is first in the comma-separated list: https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.pages.meta/pages/pages_controller_extension.htm

Selected Answer: A
https://developer.salesforce.com/docs/atlas.en-us.pages.meta/pages/pages_controller_extension.htm

I think it is C because standardController is coming first and has a Save action.
If it had not then it would have been the action of the first declared extension.
